Variation Example: A monkey throws a nut away because it has a bitter shell, & overlooks the edible kernel.
The dogs have a certificate which they give to a cat to keep it for them. A mouse destroys this certificate. Since then dogs & cats are enemies, also cats & mice.

The Dog Loses a Certificate (previously Dog Loses his Patent Right) which he had put under his tail to cross a river. The certificate guar-an teed the dogs a privilege. To search for this lost certificate, dogs look (sniff) under each other’s tails.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) Animals arrange a banquet & discover that the pepper is missing. One dog is sent to buy some but he does not return. Since then dogs sniff at one another to find that dog. Or, a dog is sent to get some medicine & does not return. (2) Some dogs are sent to heaven for an audience and, while waiting, they shit in heaven & are chased away. The next time spices or perfume are attached under their tails, but again they are chased away. These dogs do not return to the other dogs, who continue to look for the missing dogs by sniffing under each other’s tails.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) The rabbit (stag) borrows the shoes of the dog (hare) & runs away with them. Since then the dog chases the rabbit. (2) The rabbit secretly shaves the fur off the dog’s soles.

Classifications: Why Cat is Indoors & Dog Outside in Cold
Variation Example: A dog envies a cat her place indoors. They have a race & the winner gets to live indoors. The dog is faster than the cat, but loses because during the race he is attacked & detained by a beggar.

Classifications: The Lean Dog Prefers Liberty to Abundant Food & a Chain
Variation Example: A lean dog (wolf, lion, donkey, goldfinch, butterfly) would rather be free than have abundant food & be chained.
A thief tries to feed a watchdog to stop his barking. The dog realizes it & continues to bark to chase the thief away. If his master is robbed, there will be nothing left for the dog.
They unite against a common enemy (wolf)

A dog is invited to dinner by another dog but is chased off by the cook. On his way home he meets a dog who asks him how the dinner was. The first dog claims that he was so drunk that he cannot remember anything.
Two goats (horse & donkey, lion & fox) meet each other on a small bridge (stone). Neither will step aside. Both go ahead (fight with each other) & fall into the water.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A sheep & a horse have an eating contest. The sheep thinks he lost because his legs were too weak. (2) In the contest between goat & rabbit the goat wins because it ruminates.

When some animals (e.g. duck, rooster, sheep, goose, pig, goat, cat, mouse, rat) are in danger at sea the duck swims, the rooster flies up the mast, & the sheep drowns. Each animal calls out something that corresponds onomatopoetically to its characteristic voice.
At night, the animals say they have good food because the straw has not been well threshed. The master hears this & threshes the straw a second time. The animals go hungry.
A rooster advises a donkey & an ox to feign illness so they can work less. The farmer overhears this talk & has the rooster slaughtered.

Classifications: A Donkey Induces Overworked Ox to Feign Sickness
Variation Example: The donkey must do the ox’s work, so he persuades the ox to stop being ill.
The lazy horse (hard-working donkey) always waits for the next season. The diligent one is pleased with any season.
A horse refuses to help an over-burdened donkey, so it collapses. Afterwards, the horse has to carry the load alone.

A king (Charlemagne, Anu-širwān) has a bell which petitioners for justice may ring. An old horse (donkey) rings the bell & accuses his master of having chased him away because he is old & weak. The king orders the master to care for the old animal. Or, the bell is rung by a snake which is menaced by a toad. The king kills the toad & the snake shows gratitude by healing the blind king

Classifications: The Donkeys Decide to Kill the Saddler
Variation Example: Some donkeys decide to kill the saddler to get rid of their work. When an old donkey warns them that the next saddler will be inexperienced, they renounce their plan.

Classifications: Rooster, Hen, Duck, Pin, & Needle on a Journey
Variation Example: The animals & objects (also egg, millstone, dog, mouse, crayfish) hide in various parts of a house. They kill the house’s owner with their characteristic strengths. In some variants they save him (a young woman) from danger or take revenge for one of their companions who was killed.

The terrible demon, Verlioka, kills two girls & their grand -mother. The grandfather sets out for the demon’s hut to punish him. On the way he meets various objects & animals (e.g. rope, cow-dung, stick, duck, crayfish, acorn) which join him since they also want to take revenge. Together they kill the demon.

A donkey loaded with salt falls into a river. His load becomes light. A second donkey loaded with sponges (feathers) tries to reduce the weight in the same way, but he (almost) drowns, because the water makes his load heavier. Or, two birds have a contest to see which of them can fly higher while carrying a load. One bird carries cotton, the other salt. During the contest it rains, so the second bird wins.

Three animals go into a tavern. The first animal (gander, duck) orders a beer, the second (drake, goat) says they cannot pay for it, but the third (boar, turkey) reassures the innkeeper that they will pay later. Conversation between animals with imitation of animal voices.

A man sends the members of his family one after the other to pasture the goat. Back home, the goat always complains it did not get anything to eat. The man angrily sends away his sons (daughters, wife) or kills them. When he himself pastures the goat he realizes that it lies. He skins the goat (shaves its head) to punish it. The goat escapes into a foxhole & drives away a fox, a wolf & a bear. A bee (hedgehog, ant) succeeds in driving the goat away.

Classifications: Donkey Tries to Caress his Master
Variation Example: A donkey, watching how well the dog is treated, tries to flatter his master in the same way. But he is punished for his actions.

Classifications: Donkey Envies the Horse in Its Fine Trappings
Variation Example: When the horse is killed in a battle (must work in a mill) the donkey is no longer envious.

A donkey & a camel (fox & donkey, scorpion & frog) are captured because of the donkey’s singing. They have to work in a caravan. When the donkey refuses to cross a river with the caravan the camel has to carry it. The camel starts to dance & throws the donkey into the river.
A donkey (hare), disguised in a lion’s skin, spreads fear, but is found out by its voice or another characteristic feature.

Classifications: A Crow Tries to Carry Off a Lamb as an Eagle does
Variation Example: The lamb is too heavy but the jackdaw cannot drop it because it is caught in the lamb’s fleece.
A man trains a cat (monkey, dog) to hold lighted candles on its head. When a mouse runs through the room, the cat drops the candle & chases the mouse.

Classifications: A Cat Transformed to a Maiden Runs after a Mouse
Variation Example: A cat (weasel) is transformed into a woman so she can marry a young man, but she continues to chase mice.

Classifications: The Old Man Has a Rooster, the Old Woman a Hen
Variation Example: An old man envies a woman because of the eggs of her hen. He sends his rooster off to bring him some money. When the rooster returns with a lot of money, the old woman sends the hen off to do the same, but she returns without success.

Classifications: The Hen that Laid the Golden Eggs
Variation Example: A hen (goose) lays one golden egg every day (for a poor woman). Thinking that the hen must be full of gold, the woman (her husband) kills it but finds nothing special inside.

A dog & a hog argue about which one of them gives birth more easily. When the dog declares that, of all animals, she gives birth the most easily, the hog points out that the dog’s pups are blind at birth.
A rooster prefers a single seed to a lot of pearls.
The eagle as judge assigns to each species of birds their nesting places & work.

Classifications: The Trial of the Crow by the Eagle
Variation Example: A crow is tried & punished for various crimes. In order to avenge itself, the crow slanders other birds who are then also punished.

Classifications: The Election of King of Brids
Variation Example: The birds have a contest to choose their king. The wren wins by cleverness & becomes king.

The birds agree that whichever of them flies highest will be their king. The wren hides in the eagle’s wings & waits until the eagle reaches his highest point. Then the wren flies out, higher than the eagle.
